Lisa Williams
Who said writing was my choice? “They’re stuck in my head. Stories that need to be birthed feel heavy, full grown.”
Jan 25

Speaking My Fear Unlocks My Truth

On those nights when I can’t quiet
the voice in my head, the inner coward,
the afraid-the-world-will-see-me fraud,
truth is misshapen fingers on a hand
that reaches for me. Reality pushed
down deep. Push it down the rabbit hole,
where no one knows. It rots down there
absorbing the Bupropion and Temazepam.
Will a therapeutic cocktail fix me?

What if I just admit it? 
Out loud, right here, right now
that I’m angry? Afraid to believe 
in a God that allows this shit,
in a disorder that hides this shit
from x-rays, from blood tests,
and worst of all, from me
but convince kinfolk that it
don’t exist in our community.
All the while, I’m paying the toll
at every breakdown on this
gloriously messy,
infinitely endless
emotional highway.

I start to believe
what’s been working, suddenly isn’t.
I’m tired. I want to sleep, sometimes
all the time. But what if all my dogs die?
They’re my four-legged, pharmaceutical
back-up plan. Sometimes, often times
they are the reason I get out of bed.
Only pills and obligations prop me up, 
silence the maniacal voices 
and releases me into the birth canal
of reality where speaking my fear 
doesn’t make it go away. 
Speaking my fear simply unlocks 
my truth, brings me back.
